I find it amusing that a great many voters in Arizona are retirees from the east. These are people who were able to sell their homes at above normal prices and who also collect Social Security and get Medicare.

So where does this wild west mentality come from.? What leads these people to vote against their own interests? Watch Arizona a few years from now when the next generation of retirees does not have traditional pension plans, can not sell their homes at a 100% profit, then we will see the deterioration of Arizona.

Arizona does not really have much to offer other than a cheap place to retire. Phoenix gets temperatures of 118 deg. beginning in May and going through September. If it was not for the Mesa Verde nuclear power plant, the population would wither up like the corn fields. For what it is worth, Tuscon is a more liberal part of the state than Phoenix, and yet is is closer to being part of the old west.

It is the Phoenix, Surprise, Scottsdale area that rules the state. this is where the big developers concentrated the retirement communities.
Almost all of what Obama "spent" was tax cuts, and those overwhelmingly to the wealthy who were already the only ones who had benefited from our economic growth in the last three decades.

I own a broad range of digital and film cameras, with my top of the line being the Nikon D90 and D300. But the most fun I have had in a long time are two superzooms, the Canon S40 (24 - 840 mm) and Nikon P510 (24 -1000mm).

The quality is unexpectedly high given the small sensors, and the tele power opens a new world. Not tiny, but not expensive either. Check out dpreview.com's forums to see some amazing photos, including moon photos.

Dave, I enjoy your column, but I think you blew it on the Canon G1 x. Not many people buy a fairly expensive camera like this to use it in auto mode, a mode strictly for beginners. When used properly, the reviews are quite good. You did us all a favor, however, by piercing the bubble of the megapixel myth.

Another way of putting it is the most wealthy among us have pretty much gotten everything they wanted since Reagan came to office in 1981 and they want the party to continue. "Cost control" is for us, unlimited opportunity and spending is for them.

The differences between now and Reagan's time are so huge, a comparison is not valid.

The differences back then were:
The financial system was intact.
Glass-Steagall was in force. Banks were banks and not hedge funds.
The manufacturing base was around 18% of GDP. Now it's about 11%.
Demand was intact.
Median wages were much higher relative to the cost of living.
Households were not burdened with massive home equity debt.
College cost about $50 a credit hour at a state school.
Healthcare did not consume 25% of an average salary.
Most families could afford day care. It did not cost 30% to 50% of a typical second income.
The retired population was much smaller. A greater percentage of the population worked and paid taxes.
An hour in the ER cost $200, not $2000 to just lie on a gurney.
People had money in the bank and most banks paid out a 5% return and even gave out toasters to open an account.

After deregulation, the meteoric rise of the financial sector as a percentage of GDP, the collapse of manufacturing, the tremendous shift in wealth from the middle class to the top 0.1 % fueled by tax cuts, and all of the above, this is a different world now.

What happened in the 80's will never happen again because the world will never be like it was back then.

Instead of trying to defend the Obama versus Reagan argument, Democrats should argue that the comparison is completely invalid.

Mark, the most interesting exception to your comment is in California, where the redistricting process is not in the hands of the parties but independent boards.  I agree with your thesis, but the solution is a state-by-state dismantling of the redistricting process, handing it back to citizens.

Our electoral system is rigged. It has changed steadily over time, with most just not noticing the changes. On the surface, it appears the same, but that is only surface appearance. What matters is entirely new, and entirely rigged.

The changed substance is founded on data bases that those who designed the system could not have imagined.

Now gerrymandering districts has a whole new meaning, because those drawing the districts reliably predict the vote street by street, and design districts for the desired result and to bury voters they don't like.

Now media is not merely all pervasive, but based on precise marketing data and driven by money for media buys on a colossal scale. It is pure money, buying elections as one would buy a yacht.

Now truth can be manipulated very precisely, as much for elections as for the season's new products. PR has evolved into manipulation using micro-targeting and data bases and testing, again driven by fabulous amounts of cash. The old "walking around money" to affect elections is become something overwhelming in amounts and effect.

Surface appearance hides an entirely new system. Rigged. Buyable and bought.
Your first assumption is wrong.  You seem to be clueless to the current state of teaching in colleges and universities.  Take if from someone who's paying the tution bills.

I would argue with some of this author's presumptions.

In my opinion, equal to having knowledge gained is the last quality the author lists--ability to communicate. My ex-boyfriend has a PhD in Physics from Stanford, a BA from MIT, and 10 years as a research associate at Yale--and he agrees that I'm a better lecturer and teacher than he is, even with my lowly BA from UT Austin and my MFA from Northern Illinois.

We both have a passion for our field, and we both have almost equal IQs (mine is a few points higher), but I didn't have the grades or the math SAT scores to make the Ivy Leagues. However, I connect with students easier. It might be because I'm in the arts and he's in the sciences, but we both have terminal degrees in our field.

I'd say another essential quality to being a superior teacher is having bright and involved students. I've watched brilliant lecturers who can't get anything done in a classroom because 60% of the students are too busy checking Facebook on their phone or talking with their friends. No matter how well you know subject matter, if they're sleeping or don't care, it doesn't matter.

There's a myth that anyone can teach difficult students with some effort (the "Robin Williams/Michelle Pfeiffer" movie teacher), but I challenge any full Professor at Harvard to face 200 C+ students in a crowded noisy lecture hall at a third-rate school and come away with the feeling that they have done a successful job teaching anything.

Smart teachers who know their subjects would be great.  In most school systems, though, teachers have very little autonomy, can't depart from the standard syllabus, and are judged by their students' performance on multiple-choice tests in math based on mindless drill computations and in reading based on heaven knows what.  Treat them like professionals and maybe more of the talented teachers would apply -- and would stay on the job.

As a K-12 educator for the past 15 years, I wholeheartedly agree with the comments that today's school districts are mismanaged and underfunded, with overcrowded classrooms, and too much emphasis on standardized testing and uniformity of instruction in the aftermath of "No Child Left Behind."   Administrators who truly respect their most qualified teachers give them flexibility and allow them to share 'best practices' with their colleagues.  If our public school system is going to thrive and attract a new generation of talented teachers, they must provide a nurturing environment, mentoring from veteran educators, and better salaries.
Exactly.  I am familiar with this pattern.

Jzzy55, please come to the mountains of Virginia-- my school board *dreams* of finding teaching prospects such as you!

The sad thing is, given our very modest resources in this rural region, we may attract highly-qualified new teachers at the bottom of their pay scale, but we are unlikely to retain them once their resume bulks up. The cost of living is our biggest competitor.

But our benefits package includes ready access to the Jefferson National Forest :-)

Your experience speaks not only to the inane, destructive bureacracy, but also to the prevalence of ageism in the public school teaching. You have my sympathy. Mine is similar. Excellent academic credentials, rich work and life experience, and a demonstrated commitment to re-training and learning won't keep you from being boxed out of the opportunity to teach. This is not to say that anyone who steps into a public school classroom won't have a ton to learn. But wanting to and demonstrating the commitment, no matter how much we hear about the need for better teachers, doesn't get you far enough.

I retrained and became licensed as a teacher three years ago. I had graduated with honors from a public Ivy and worked successfully as a writer for over 20 years before attempting to start a second career in education. I've never found a full-time or permanent job as a teacher (in spite of glowing references and having worked/student taught in a good district) because no principal need hire someone with no prior experience. I couldn't compete with people who had been there and done that. Perhaps I was better educated ("more intellectual") than many of those experienced folks, but I still didn't get a job. Districts don't want to spend scarce time or money training new teachers if they don't have to. And they don't have to in the current economy, where there is a glut of qualified teachers (meaning licensed, experienced and trained in whatever curriculum the district favors).

While my education and references got me interviews (a few), I heard "Nice to meet you, good luck, you have a lot to offer but we're looking for someone with experience" at the closing of every interview. It got to the point where I started prescreening interview opportunities to make sure they knew I had not yet had my own classroom. Usually the HR person said, "Oh, didn't realize, I'll get back to you." They didn't. Saved me another pointless and frustrating interview.

The fact that I was cheap (bottom of pay scale) made no difference, BTW.

Good points, which could be well applied to "grade school" teachers dismissed as second class intellects in this article.  However, we really need creative, dedicated teachers who also have a lot of subject area knowledge.  In elementary school, teachers have to teach a myriad of subjects.  The more they know about all these subjects, the more they can apply creativity and dedication in a focused intelligent way.. The other "problem" which concerns where the best and brightest go after college has to be connected with what various professions offer.  Dedication does not pay bills, nor provide a lifestyle that many desire. So, despite all the blather, the best and brightest are not going to become teachers unless they can make a decent living and have some chance for advancement.

The difference is motivation. Primary and secondary school teachers are largely responsible for finding creative ways to motivate their learners, to inspire them. This cannot be compared to college students who are, as the author stated, paying large sums of money to be educated by the best and brightest.
Teachers must be adept at connecting with their students, and this is not the case for lecturers at the university level. What this article lacks is a valid analogy. Good teaching is a product of finding the right personality types.

The most oxymoronic statement I ever heard Reagan utter (and there were many),  was that Government was always the problem--and he said it with a straight face, in spite of himself being the head of Government at the time.  I would submit most of our present problems had their genesis during his tenure.  The best I can say about the man is that he was slightly better than all the little extreme clones he seeded while in office.  Many of them are now the source of our broken political system.  I also would not be surprised if future historians trace our decline, point by point,  back to 1980.  They might even describe this period, in the words of Gordon Gecko as "The Age of Greed."  Individualism and selfishness run amuck.

Great commentary.  But the first line is what republicans want us all to believe, which is blatantly untrue.  Rather, it is classic non-sequiter.  America outspent every other communist, socialist, democratic, dictatorship, monarchy on earth, yet none of them also collapsed as a result of our spending.  Last time we checked, North Korea, Cuba, Sweden, Iran, et al, are all still here.

And yet, through it all, the public sector has continued to expand and wrap its increasingly large tentacles into all aspects of US society. Can anyone blame the mainstream media, Congress, and "the government" for losing trust in these public organizations? I, for one, cannot.

The "job creator" class already has outstanding secondary schools with small classrooms sizes, motivated teachers, little need for discipline control, and tons of ancillary resources. So, I don't quite see what the problem is.

The underclass should consider itself lucky to have schools. The less they learn the better -- education and potential critical thinking can get in the way. True, we need some extra brains for some industries...But we can import the needed brains. Besides, it may be cheaper to move the industries abroad.

The headmaster of a local private school with about 800 students earned a doctorate in quantum chemistry with an advisor who later received a Nobel Prize in Chemistry. He has a great school, but, in general, a superior intellectual would be a nut to teach in East Baton Rouge Parish.

Not to mention, but taking the public out of public education, the Repubs are giving all this money to their friends - the charter school heads (the teachers make coolie wages), the testing companies and the textbook publishers out of Texas.  It's called Privatization.

Higher education is currently able to select from a pool of talented professionals primarily because college teaching and research jobs are in high demand.  Most graduate programs are only able to accept a small percentage of the smart students who apply to them (even though they are all usually at the top of their undergraduate classes) and most professor positions these days have 100+ quality applicants for every open job.  This makes it hard for people to break into this line of work, but it does ensure that the people who are hired are usually very smart, driven and ambitious.  This is not the case with elementary and high school teaching positions.  Often the best and the brightest think they would be selling themselves short by going into teaching.  Our current Republican party is busy making this situation even worse by demonizing teachers, cutting their health insurance, micromanaging their teaching and generally making this vital profession even less appealing.  The first step in fixing the situation is to vigorously oppose any Republican who promotes this destructive way of thinking.

A lot depends on the particular school. I received a decent public school education, but (except for a few stand-out exceptions) most of the teachers appeared to more concerned with discipline and just getting through the day than in really helping students understand and appreciate the subjects they were teaching. I don't blame the teachers for this. Their main job was to maintain orderly classrooms, go through uninspiring textbooks and make students complete handouts. This level of regimentation was oppressive to both the students and the teachers, but the powers that be decreed that it must be so.

In college, I found professors who designed their own curriculum and were passionate about most of the subjects they were teaching. Even if they weren't always great lecturers, they were experts in their field and had a lot to offer students who took advantage of their expertise--asking questions, visiting office hours etc. This points to an important difference. In high school, the burden is on the teacher to impose learning on often reluctant students. In college, the burden is on the student to study, work hard and learn from the professor. Reluctant students are not welcome. They are free to fail.

In high school, students have to be there even if they don't want to. In college, students have to WANT to be there if they are going to succeed.
High school and higher education really are not the same.

Just because your have your doctorate does not mean you will be a great teacher.

The worst teachers I ever had were in College.

Until someone is willing to dismantle the layers of bureaucrats that stifle
creative teaching in our schools - nothing will change.

As you said - new programs will arise and be forced upon faculty and students
and then fall out of favour and another "New and Improved" program will
arise and be tried and found lacking...

Being compassionate and patient and willing to try just about anything
to help/motivate students to learn is the key to be a successful teacher.

It helps to be bright, but not too bright.

Better Pay, more control over the classroom and what and how you teach
could draw in better teachers.

Anecdotal evidence, i.e. my experience as a parent of six (beautiful, academically top achieving, kind, some of them already contributing to the society and their professions) children and as someone who tries to keep his eyes open and see things in context: Today, for example, I looked at the Yearbook of our 5th grader and right on page one: Photos of no less than 78 (!!!) female teachers and staff and only 5 (five) males (2 teachers and 3 janitors/custodians). Post WWII, with the population expanding rapidly, they could get jobs in almost any area of the country; which let their hubbies take the best jobs that they could get, without compromising (kerr) the job the little Mrs. could take.

The best idea in this essay concerns getting rid of a destructive bureaucracy (not inane: destructive). But how are you going to do that? Teaching is so difficult that there are enormous incentives to be "promoted" out of the classroom, especially if you're not a very good teacher--and once you are moved up, you make more money and get to crack the whip on people who are better teachers than you were. Meantime, you're at the mercy of the truly awful local politics of our 18000 or so local school boards. Perverse incentives of every kind.

I've seen this in all six public high schools where I've taught, from very good to very bad ones--in every one, the administration was essentially a waste from an educational point of view, but also difficult to get rid of because of our complex laws, politics, and parental pressure. I've escaped to college teaching: it's a hundred times easier and more productive, as Gutting says.

If you were able to move K-12 schools to a model of teacher-run collectives--with an administrative support staff, but no ex-teacher "bosses"--that were accountable for student performance and also paid competitive wages with the other professions, you'd make real progress. But we won't do that: it makes too much sense.

I read several good ideas about improving the quality of the pool of teaching prospects and they target attracting smarter, better qualified people (as evidenced by their good grades) to the profession.  Too much focus on teachers as if they are the problem to solve.  What could we do to improve the raw material that teachers are charged with developing?
